35.speaker: Wyll
35.text: Twice, Mizora's held my feet to the fire - and twice was I burnt.
35.context: NodeContext: With some consideration, but with no element of self-pity.

19.speaker: Wyll
19.text: But my father will live. We will return the Grand Duke to his people. And forever, a devil's leash will choke me.
19.context: NodeContext: With some consideration, but with no element of self-pity.

74.speaker: Player
74.text: You did the right thing, the selfless thing.

63.speaker: Wyll
63.text: That means a lot. But understand, I don't plan to wallow in self-pity. More than anything, I'm elated that there's hope yet for my father.

58.speaker: Player
58.text: It wasn't much of a sacrifice. You were already pacted, right?

61.speaker: Wyll
61.text: But my soul belongs to a far more fiendish villain now. The archdevil Zariel.

69.speaker: Wyll
69.text: I don't need to tell you what evil she's capable of, what brutality she's wrought.
69.context:
NodeContext: [Tom P] Pickup:
Add some anger and fire to this line

59.speaker: Wyll
59.text: Karlach can tell you what evil she's capable of, what brutality she's wrought.

21.speaker: Wyll
21.text: She could raise me as a wardevil and loose me on the Coast. She could name me a patron and bid me collect souls for her cause.
21.context:
NodeContext: [Tom P] Pickup:
Sounds too casual in original read, needs more vitriol

16.speaker: Wyll
16.text: My pact ends at death, and Zariel may want more than just fodder for her front line.
16.context:
NodeContext: [Tom P] Pickup:
Give this a bit of intensity and make it more final

54.speaker: Wyll
54.text: Well - that's enough self-pity for one day. If anything, I should be elated that there's hope yet for my father.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: I wouldn't give up hope. Maybe we'll find another way out.

7.speaker: Wyll
7.text: Sometimes, fate closes a door for good. The bolt is fastened, the key is destroyed, and a wish is forever locked away.

67.speaker: Wyll
67.text: The Hells will take my soul. I'll make my peace with it - I have once already, after all.

5.speaker: Wyll
5.text: Besides, there's no time to wallow in self-pity. More than anything, I'm elated that there's hope yet for my father.

60.speaker: Wyll
60.text: We should hurry to this mystery prison and retrieve father, before Mizora tries pulling more tricks.

3.speaker: Player
3.text: Let's get going, then. We've got a duke to rescue.

17.speaker: Player
17.text: We're bound to anger Gortash if we go messing in his prison.

55.speaker: Wyll
55.text: Gortash is the Black Lord's thrall. A liar, a tyrant. He'd sooner have our heads than share his domain.

70.speaker: Wyll
70.text: His anger is inevitable. I didn't sign this pact just to let my father rot in Gortash's prison.

57.speaker: Player
57.text: Your father's still got a tadpole in his head, remember? Rescuing doesn't mean curing him.

68.speaker: Wyll
68.text: This prison's in the Lower City. Let's move.

11.speaker: Player
11.text: Chin up, Wyll. I'm sure you'll make a great soldier in Zariel's army when you die.

73.speaker: Wyll
73.text: I'm not sure if you meant to be funny or mean. Hells, I'm not even sure it matters - you're still good for a laugh.

47.speaker: Wyll
47.text: Zariel could do more than conscript me into her legions as a lemure.

34.speaker: Wyll
34.text: We will knock him out if we need to. Or restrain -

14.speaker: Narrator
14.text: *Your skull vibrates in concord with the Astral Prism.*

50.speaker: GROUP_Emperors
50.text: Bring me to your duke. I will shield him as I shield you.

31.speaker: GROUP_Emperors
31.text: Better to bring him into the fold than to leave you distracted by regret.

9.speaker: Wyll
9.text: Well then. I'm not about to say 'no'.

42.speaker: Wyll
42.text: I spent seven years choked by Mizora's leash. And I spent seven years hoping to break free.

13.speaker: Wyll
13.text: I never knew freedom could taste so bittersweet.

45.speaker: Player
45.text: It's a little late for remorse, don't you think?

15.speaker: Wyll
15.text: My father is gone. His blood paid for my freedom. What sort of man would I be if I had no remorse?

33.speaker: Wyll
33.text: But I won't miss the Mizora's leash squeezing my neck. Tomorrow, I celebrate my gain. But today, I mourn my loss.

51.speaker: Wyll
51.text: My father will die. His blood will pay for my freedom. What sort of man would I be if I had no remorse?

12.speaker: Player
12.text: You are your own man now, Wyll. It's better this way.

8.speaker: Wyll
8.text: I have to believe that. I'm not the Hells' puppet in life, nor its warrior in death. The Blade will be guiding his own hand.

23.speaker: Wyll
23.text: But freedom was paid in my father's blood. Tomorrow, I celebrate my gain. Today, I mourn my loss.

27.speaker: Narrator
27.text: *A moment passes. In the stillness, you find a mote of tranquility.*

20.speaker: Wyll
20.text: The Ravengard name now lives solely with me. I will make it count for something.

44.speaker: Player
44.text: Your father's not dead yet, Wyll. Maybe there's a way to save him.

10.speaker: Wyll
10.text: I signed his life away before the Hells' witnesses. It would be easier to drink the Styx down to the last drop than to alter his fate.

30.speaker: Wyll
30.text: I'd be a fool to wish otherwise.

0.speaker: Wyll
0.text: We should pursue this great wyrm of legend. What ally could prove more fearsome than a raging dragon?

24.speaker: Wyll
24.text: We obtain Orin's Netherstone and take back our minds - and the city - from the brain.

2.speaker: Wyll
2.text: We obtain Gortash's Netherstone and take back our minds - and the city - from the brain.

26.speaker: Wyll
26.text: We obtain the final two Netherstones and take back our minds - and the city - from the brain.

46.speaker: Wyll
46.text: We tear the elder brain's hooks out of this city.

18.speaker: Player
18.text: I'd like to talk about something else.

56.speaker: Wyll
56.text: But freedom will be paid in my father's blood. Tomorrow, I celebrate my gain. Today, I mourn my loss.

6.speaker: Player
6.text: A fantastic power play. With your father gone, you can rise up and take his place.

37.speaker: Wyll
37.text: It's a tantalising prospect. How better to protect the frontiers, than as a Grand Duke of Baldur's Gate? What evils could I vanquish with the Flaming Fist at my command?

36.speaker: Wyll
36.text: Presuming, of course, the people can stomach the sight of these gods-damned horns.
36.context:
NodeContext: [Tom P] Pickup:
Add some disdain on "these gods-damned horns"

25.speaker: Wyll
25.text: The leash has been broken, and my father is dead. Tomorrow, I celebrate my gain. But today, I mourn my loss.

53.speaker: Wyll
53.text: The leash has been broken, and my father left for dead. Tomorrow, I celebrate my gain. But today, I mourn my loss.

43.speaker: Player
43.text: I thought you never regretted taking the pact.

40.speaker: Wyll
40.text: I didn't. I don't. My sacrifice kept Baldur's Gate safe from Tiamat's rage.

38.speaker: Wyll
38.text: But that doesn't mean that the leash never chafed, that I was content to lap up whatever nonsense Mizora fed me.
